ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Judith AMendt
Judith Ament
Judith Ament
Judith Ament
I worked most closely with Natalie.
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Lei was an amazing TA, incredible knowledgable and always willing to help. I was so happy and lucky to have had him!
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Lei was amazing - always clearly answered question and he was always accessible - such a great TA!
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Lei was great....very attentive, willing to brainstorm through problems and always available.
Instructor: Natalie Price  Natalie Price
Instructor: Natalie Price  Natalie... sorry, no question prompt here, not sure what to write.
Instructor: Natalie Price  Natalie
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Noel Aloysius
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  Noel
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  He is very knowledgeable and helpful.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Larry Bonneau deserves all the credit in the world.good hands on, well designed course. you'll learn a lot.sorta heavy handed with the physics in the first part of the course, sort of felt like filler (at times)
Judith was an excellent TA! Very accessible and very knowledgeable.
No further comments.
I also worked with Katherine during the final project and she was beyond helpful. She knew ENVI very well and could answer my deeper conceptual questions about what the program was doing best.

Everything in this class was great except for the materials. The text-book was good in itself but not directly linked to the weekly lectures so it was hard to go over the material that was difficult to understand from the lectures because the book chapters attached to that lecture were not necessarily the same (although they were broadly related). So it would be better if there was more material or somehow a summary sheet of the concepts in more detail. For example, the powerpoint presentations were great but if one did not understand them and we wanted to look up more details on a particular slide it was very difficult to sort through the 300pg book and try to find the answer.
NA

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: labs, exposure to real research.
The entire teaching staff was great. Guest lecturers were great as well.
The best aspects involved the links between remote sensing and other geospatial technologies.

Profs. Smith and Lee were great teachers and it was clear that they have passion for the work that they do. They were accessible to students and were genuinely interested in our projects and questions during class. I liked that even in a large class, they made an effort to come to our lab sections to give us feedback on our course projects. Larry was so helpful in both lecture and lab.It was helpful to break down the final project into the prospectus, progress report, and roundtable discussions, so we were forced to get a jump on the project early in the semester, and also to receive feedback.
the project and the field trip!
Lab sessions and final project
I enjoyed lab section. The sections were well organized and useful.

I liked that the class included students from so many departments, yet the remote sensing methodology can be applied to all these fields. The instruction was great, and the lab well set up. forcing us to do a challenging final project at the end really got us learning the software and methods better.
labwork and guest lectures - learning about how remote sensing is used in the research of different Yale faculty
The background physics of radiation and the final project.
The final project. The freedom to explore ENVI and more broadly, remote sensing and its applications to an environmental issue I care about was just what I hoped to get out of the course.
Individual project - why not started / time given in labs, earlier? TAs not very accessible outside of lab time, so help to start a project earlier was entirely fielded by Larry.
Very applicable for my field of study.

It was very exciting to learn Envi and to learn a hands-on tool. The final project was a great product because we were able to link all of the material we learned in class in one project. Itwas great!
Fascinating course material, well taught, excellent explanations, skills-driven class

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: too aggressively math and phsyics oriented in the first half of the course. no reason to learn why classification and its equations work the way they do math wise.

The workload is too heavy for a 3 credit course. The labs took much longer than 2 hours to complete (the calculations took ~2 hours per week, but answering the questions took several more hours every week). The current course minus the project seems like 3 credits worth of work; the project could be an additional 1 credit. Alternatively, I would opt to take the course minus the project as a 2 credit course; the project could be an optional 1 credit.

While the labs + presentation + paper seemed a little heavy, the thing that needs the most improvement is expectations about the final projects. The instructors seemed to have particular applications of remote sensing that they did and did not like, with particular things that they hoped to see in the final project. I think it would have been more useful to consider novel ways of applying the technology since there are may resources for common methods like change detection or land cover evaluation.
data management. The FAQ website could be better organized too. Maybe more assigned reading from the literature.

It would have been helpful to have a better understanding of the grading breakdown-- how much of our final grade was from the labs, homework, exam, final project etc. We didn't get much guidance on how our 10 minute presentation was going to be evaluated, and with only 10 minutes, it was difficult to know which aspects of the project to focus on.I much preferred Profs. Smith and Lee's lectures to the guest lectures. While it was interesting to see some applications of remote sensing, the format of some of the lectures didn't seem suited to an introductory remote sensing class, rather a seminar for others in a similar field as the professors. I wish more attention had been given in these lectures to the methods the professors used and why, rather than their results.Smaller groups for the field trip may have been better.
i wish the labs were more related to real projects, although I know this is logistically hard. It would have been easier for processes to really stick in my memory!
N/A

Instructor expectations were VAGUE at best. Students were never familiarized with the course's evaluation practices.There is a lot of material and tools not covered in lab sections (managing clouds, heat islands, etc.). It would be excellent if what is NOT taught is made known to the student so at least we know what remote sensing tools are capable of and can apply them to our final projects.EVERY student who submits a progress report on time deserves at least a few sentences of feedback from an instructor. Otherwise, why do this?

We need more support for final projects from Larry and the TAs it was pretty hectic in the lab. While we had to turn in a prospectus and progress report, we got very little feedback, and I think we needed more help in terms of direction and methods for our projects. It would be useful to have TAs (several at a time if possible) staffed in the lab for a full 2 weeks before projects are due.

1. poor organization with 2 profs, 1 lab coordinator and multiple TAs - there was often a lack in accountability for lab / project / HW questions.2. one of the most difficult parts of the project was finding and obtaining the proper images. we had no experience in this because it was already provided for us in our labs. in the future, it might be helpful to do a lab of how to navigate the Glovis, etc. websites and download images.3. field trip to collect GPS points was less relevant bc we didn't have the chance to import the points into an ArcView program and match their locations with the Landsat image.

The labs. I'm not sure how the format of them can be improved. The instructions were very clear, but because the steps are so rote and available, I always left lab feeling like I had just followed a protocol instead of learning a skill. In the final project, it was useful to have to use the techniques we learned in lecture and lab and that process is what made them stick.
See above - start individual project earlier, with more explicit relationship with TA established (like, is it their job to help with projects, or just to show up to lab?)
I think the labs should be in a form of question which the student has to work a whole week to solve.

Office hours should be set weekly especially for the first half of the course. (this is when problem sets are due). It was difficult to know who to go to for questions and I had to ask the Teaching assistants for a favor to help me with problem sets. There were so many TAs for the course that nobody wanted to take the responsibility to meet with me. So it should be made clear from the professor to the Teaching Assitants when then should show up for office hours on a weekly basis so that the students can meet them.

More guidance for final project and more clear communication of expectations--flexibility is appreciated but the project design was so open-ended and requirements ambiguous, which made it more difficult

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: great relationship

The labs involved a little too much button pushing and not enough conceptual problem solving, though I did leave with a beginner's capacity to navigate the ENVI software platform. I would have preferred having selected a research topic at the beginning of the term, and applying all of the labs to it along the way.

In the labs, I wish there would have been more of a discussion of WHY we were using a specificmethod, and integrate some of the background material into the labs, rather than just giving us a step by step guide.While I understand that there was so much material to get through in the labs, when we started our final projects, we didn't have any practice yet in downloading our own data and learning how to get it into a useable format in ENVI. I would have liked practice in learning how to navigate Landsat, MODIS, etc. databases and how to deal with some of the problems with getting the data in a useable format (i.e. Landsat striping, missing data/outliers, etc.)-- more realistic examples, rather than having everything perfectly set up for us.
made total sense
Well structured, no thing to blame
Yes. The labs linked in well with the lectures.
Really great- the labs followed what we learned in lecture.

it would have been interesting to spend more time reviewing studies that use remote sensing and looking at their methodology to understand what exactly they are doing. Its more realistic that in the future we will be looking at information gathered from remote sensing rather than actually manipulating the remote sensing information ourselves.
Relationship was good. I think it would be helpful to start working on the final project earlier in semester because it was a great learning opportunity.

It was effective. Perhaps the labs could be a bit more open ended and require a little more exploration. It was good that often the questions asked about the underlying concepts of what we were working with. The conceptual lab questions were the most effective.
Good
not very good -see my response to #17
Very effective, opportunity to explore in lab what was taught in lecture was well-designed

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: My lab TF was Judith Ament, who was fantastic!I am not sure who grades the labs, but it was incredibly slow. I didn't get my first graded lab returned to me until I had finished the 5th or 6th lab! I can understand why it takes so long to grade them -- the labs have way too many questions and are way too long.
Teaching assistant was knowledgeable and accessible. She was always willing to help and to brainstorm when she did not know of the proper solution. A fine balance of confidence and humility.
TAs were helpful in lab, but not as helpful in projects bc we were each working on specialized topics. Lab coordinator and professors should have been more active in project assistance

This is obviously a very demanding course for a TA and I appreciated Natalie's availability to answer questions and her hard work throughout. However, I think the most effective TAs for this course are the ones with lots of research experience using ENVI and remote sensing.
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Lei was always very helpful and knew the material. He was prepared for lab sections and responded to email questions promptly.
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Lei was fantastic. I really can't think of any way he needs to improve. Very attentive, responsive and knowledgeable!
Instructor: Lei Zhao  Amazing! very knowledgeable and extremely helpful and patient.

Instructor: Natalie Price  Natalie was helpful if I had questions/problems with parts of the labs, but wasn't as helpful with broader questions about the lab or lecture material.I think the TFs should have attended more lectures, because sometimes they didn't seem to know much about what we were learning in lecture or be able to discuss questions about lecture material.
Instructor: Natalie Price  I think a teaching assistant should know the lab material backwards and forwards...she did not and could not often clearly answer student questions.
Instructor: Natalie Price  More one-on-one help with the final project; I think she just didn't have too wide-ranging experience with remote sensing so couldn't suggest ways to improve projects
Instructor: Noel Ramesh Aloysius  I had a hard time following his explanations.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: earth science in general floats my boat
See below.

I hadn't taken remote sensing before but see it as a large part of my research going forward indefinitely. I am excited to have taken this first step and continue to learn more about it. This is why I would have liked to have the labs be more related to our final projects, because for me this was a first step in a much larger journey, and I really enjoyed the final project.
Very essential to my research.
Remote sensing is a valuable part of natural resource&forest management
Remote sensing is one of the main methods I plan to use in my research.
very much linked to my master's thesis project
Good development of technical skills that will be very helpful for the type of work I hope to do

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: earth science floats my boat, an alternate career perhaps. at least a skill i wanna know.
This course complimented my other geospatial studies, filling in blanks and bridging gaps. I took it after taking the GIS courses and wanting greater capacity with multi-band image manipulation.
I plan to use remote sensingas the base methodology in my masters research.
Helpful for my research
Very practical occupational skill and understanding to have.
I need it for summer research
It relates to my research.
My advisor suggested it.
Research project
to work on side project that is linked to my master's thesis
Develop skills in the use of ENVI, get comfortable with the applications of remote sensing in my field

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes!
Yes.
I think I gained valuable skills that will be very helpful in my future research. Overall, the course met my expectations.

Yes, as an introductory course, i felt I learned a great deal about the physics behind remote sensing and about how to use the software. The project and labs helped me understand how to apply that knowledge.
Yes!
Yes.

Yes- but I feel like a remote sensing baby! There should be more offerings of advanced courses in specific topics- I know Karen offers an advanced course in change detection, but we should have an advanced course on biomass mapping, or atmospheric chemistry, or meterology, or agriculture...
remote sensing is complicated, and this course is just the beginning
Yes, although I feel as though there is still a lot more to learn in ENVI.
yes.
Yes
yes!
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
work groups were incredibly helpful for the homework assignments and the labs!
N/A
n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: go for it. you'll learn the skills you wanted to learn.
Don't take this course during a semester when you have a heavy course load because this class is a lot of work.

See if you can get the professors to let you use a research topic of choice throughout the term to apply the labs to. The final project is highly time consuming, and it would have been nice to spread that out over the course of the term instead of having to do it during the final few weeks. Because of the lab structure, you can't physically start the term projects until very late in the term, necessitating long hours at the end of the term.
take it, and try to think about your project as you go through the labs.
It is very important to have basic remote sensing knowledge.
Recommended. Ask questions and get started on the final project as soon as you can.
This class might have been one of my favorites so far at FES. Take it! It is worth the work.
Pick a final project you are very interested in, in possible - you will get more out of it.
Start projects early to get the most out of the course so you have plenty of time to test out different methods and to challenge yourself.
Start project early, ask for guidance on sources of data early, forge relationship with TA early
take a basic physics course or read up on basic physics before taking class.
Take it! It is a solid, well-taught course that spans many topics and inspires interest in the field. It quickly became my favorite course of the term.
